docs.lead_paragraph: Findings of two new studies, one hopeful and the other a cause for concern, were released today, the day before the opening here of the 14th annual International AIDS conference. Thai and American health officials reported here today that the first nationwide program in a developing country to prevent transmission of the virus that causes AIDS from a mother to her newborn, in Thailand, has proved highly successful.

headline.main: Drug Reduces H.I.V. Rates in Newborns, Thai Study Shows

docs.abstract: Thai and American health officials report that first nationwide program in developing country to prevent transmission of virus that causes AIDS from mother to her newborn, in Thailand, has proved highly successful; second report, from University of California at San Francisco, says small but rising number of people there are being infected with strains of HIV that are resistant to certain drugs commonly used to treat the infection; two reports are issued in Barcelona, Spain, on day before opening of 14th annual International AIDS Conference (M)

docs.snippet: LOVE WORKS LIKE THIS   Moving From One Kind of Life   to Another.   By Lauren Slater.   Random House, $21.95.

docs.lead_paragraph: NICOLE ANNE THIBODEAU was single and 19 years old in 1997 when she learned that she was pregnant. Counting on the money she earned working as a secretary and bookkeeper for a small architectural firm in Chester, Ms. Thibodeau felt comfortable that she could support herself and her child. But when medical complications arose and she had to make frequent trips to the doctor, she said her bosses at Design Group One Architects began hinting that her absences were becoming a problem. And then on a Friday afternoon in April, 15 minutes before she was scheduled to leave, Ms. Thibodeau was told that she was fired, effective immediately.

headline.main: Decision Raises Questions About Discrimination Law

docs.abstract: Article on questions raised by Connecticut Supreme Court's recent decision in company's favor in 1997 suit filed by former secretary Nicole Anne Thibodeau against Design Group One Architects; Thibodeau, 19 and single at time, maintains she was fired because she was pregnant; company cited poor job performance but argued for dismissal based on state law that exempts businesses with fewer than three employees from sexual discrimination suits; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It started with a premonition from a friend who was crazy, though mostly in good ways. She was a storyteller with a hooting laugh, and one afternoon in front of my wife and daughters, she launched into a tale about how she'd once gotten a job when she showed the boss that she could fit her fist in her mouth. When my friend finished her tale, we all realized that my younger daughter, then 5, had her fist all the way inside her mouth. Out of nowhere, the friend said, ''That child is going to be pregnant by the time she's 15.'' I thought of those words the day my friend died. I thought of them again the day I learned that my daughter was pregnant. She was 15. Her older sister is on the dean's list at her university, and she's always so well behaved that I sometimes worry she's too good. Maybe my younger daughter feels she has to carve out her own identity by doing what she pleases. She smokes cigarettes and marijuana and doesn't care who knows. She promises to drop out of school when she turns 16. We used to ground her until she realized that there was no way we could forcibly make her do anything she didn't want to do.
docs.abstract: Anonymously written Lives column describes events, feelings and family tensions leading up to writer's 15-year-old daughter's decision to have abortion; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Charlie's Ghost,'' by Bill Keller (column, June 29): Mr. Keller describes the imperfect and difficult choices surrounding prenatal diagnosis. But I disagree with his characterization of those who view abortion as an ''inalienable right'' as treating ''these decisions as if they were clear-cut.''
docs.abstract: Temple University Asst Prof Susan Markens letter disagrees with Bill Keller's June 29 column on prenatal genetic screening and abortion rights

docs.lead_paragraph: Upholding a lower-court decision, the Constitutional Court ruled that the government must provide AIDS drugs to pregnant women infected with H.I.V. to prevent its transmission to unborn babies. In April, government officials agreed to provide the drugs in public hospitals after months of wavering. But the court's decision was still cheered by advocates for AIDS patients. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AIDS Ruling

docs.abstract: South African Constitutional Court, upholding lower-court decision, rules that government must provide AIDS drugs to pregnant women infected with HIV to prevent transmission to unborn babies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Alice M. Stewart, an epidemiologist who first demonstrated the link between X-rays of pregnant women and disease in their children, a finding that changed medical practice, died on June 23 in Oxford, England. A resident of the countryside outside Oxford, she was 95. Dr. Stewart, who became one of the most authoritative critics of the safety of the American nuclear weapons program and a leading proponent of the idea that no level of exposure to radiation is safe, came to prominence in 1956 for her report on prenatal X-rays.

headline.main: Alice Stewart, 95; Linked X-Rays to Diseases
